revision.text:
{{short description|Former bowling center in Costa Mesa, California}} {{featured article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox venue | name = Kona Lanes | former_names = New Kona Lanes (1980s) | image = File:Kona Lanes roadside sign.JPG | image_size = 220 | caption = The Kona Lanes Bowl roadside sign
in 2002 | coordinates = {{Coord|33.671083|-117.920306|type:landmark_region:US-CA}} | address = 2699 [[Harbor Boulevard|Harbor Blvd.]]
[[Costa Mesa, California]], U.S. | type = Bowling center | architect = Powers, Daly, & DeRosa | builder = Quigley & Clark | built = 1958 | opened = {{start date and age|1958|paren=y}} | renovated = 1981 | closed = {{end date and age|2003|paren=y}} | demolished = 2003 | owner = Jack Mann Jr. (last) }} '''Kona Lanes''' was a [[bowling]] center in [[Costa Mesa, California]], that opened in 1958 and closed in 2003 after 45 years in business. Known for its futuristic design, it featured 40 wood-floor bowling lanes, a [[amusement arcade|game room]], a lounge, and a coffee shop that eventually became a [[Mexican cuisine|Mexican diner]]. Built during the advent of [[Googie architecture]], its [[Polynesian culture|Polynesian]] [[Tiki culture|Tiki]]-themed styling extended from the large [[neon sign|roadside sign]] to the building's neon lights and exaggerated rooflines. When Kona Lanes was demolished in 2003, it was one of the last remaining examples of the Googie style in the region; its sister center, Java Lanes in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], was razed in 2004. Much of Kona's equipment was sold prior to the demolition; the distinctive sign was saved and sent to [[Cincinnati]], where a portion is on permanent display in the [[American Sign Museum]]. Costa Mesa's planning commission approved a proposal to build a department store on the site; following public outcry, those plans were scrapped. In 2010, the still-vacant land was [[zoning|rezoned]] for [[Old age#Senior citizen|senior citizens']] apartments and commercial development. Construction on the apartments began ten years after Kona Lanes was demolished. ==History== ===Early years=== [[File:Kona comparison.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Kona Lanes before (top) and after a remodel taming its "ostentatious rooflines" (Scott Martelle, ''Los Angeles Times'')]] Kona Lanes opened in 1958, featuring the Tiki-inspired signage and architecture that became popular following [[World War II]],{{cite AV media|people=Yaussy, Carolyn (video journalist)|publisher=Carolyn Yaussy|via=[[YouTube]]|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|title=The American Sign Museum|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nXG6Hjlmc8w&t=2m33s|medium=video|at=2:33–2:54|quote=[Tod Swormstedt:] The guys came back from the war in the Pacific, they'd been in those kind of Hawaiian-flavored bars and restaurants, they came back to the States after the war, there was this whole advent of the Tiki look.|date=January 22, 2014|accessdate=May 27, 2014}}{{indent|3}}{{cite news|last=Epting|first=Chris|url=http://articles.hbindependent.com/2010-06-09/news/hbi-pipeline061010_1_polynesian-pop-tiki-motif-tiki-culture/2|title=Tracking Tiki culture, influence|work=[[Huntington Beach Independent]]|page=2|date=June 9, 2010|accessdate=August 15, 2015|quote=[Chris Jepsen, Orange County Historical Society:] Want to theme your back yard? Go Polynesian! ... The theme was fully embraced in Orange County as it became almost a status—a sign of class and distinction. A normal bowling alley now became 'Kona Lanes', and it stood out. Developers even incorporated the Tiki theme into their housing projects.}}{{efn|Tod Swormstedt is founder and executive director of the [[American Sign Museum]]; he is not identified by name in Yaussy's video, but is recognizable from news publications.{{cite news|last=Linhardt|first=Becky|url=http://www.cincinnatimagazine.com/features/sign-guy3/|title=Sign Guy|work=[[Cincinnati (magazine)|Cincinnati]]|date=April 1, 2013|accessdate=March 26, 2017}} He is a recognized expert on signs.{{cite book|author=[[United States Department of the Interior]]|title=Preserving Historic Architecture: The Official Guidelines|date=February 8, 2013|page=|publisher=[[Skyhorse Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-5107-2044-2}}}} including what the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' called its "flamboyant [[neon lighting|neon lights]] and ostentatious [[roofline]]s meant to attract motorists like moths". The building on [[Harbor Boulevard]] near Adams Avenue was one of three in the Googie style that architects Powers, Daly, & DeRosa designed at around the same time;{{sfnp|Chattel, Inc.|2013|p=16}} Kona Lanes and its sister center, Java Lanes,{{cite news|last=Douglas|first=Leo|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/2004-07-01/music/the-birth-the-death-the-ghost/full/|title=The Birth, the Death, the Ghost|work=[[OC Weekly]]|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=July 1, 2004|accessdate=January 24, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721174815/http://www.ocweekly.com/2004-07-01/music/the-birth-the-death-the-ghost/full/|archivedate=July 21, 2015|df=mdy-all}} used names that suggested [[Polynesia|South Pacific]] island locales.{{sfnp|Chattel, Inc.|2013|p=16}} Author Andrew Hurley called them "expensive and attractive buildings that screamed, 'Have fun here{{single double}},{{sfnp|Hurley|2002|p=155}} and Kona retained much of that atmosphere over the years. Its massive neon-lit street sign remained for the life of the building, and Kona was the only bowling establishment in the area to reject [[automatic scorer|automatic scoring]] equipment throughout its existence.{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Newman|title=Pins Set to Fall On Kona Lanes|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-04-05/news/export25232_1_lanes-general-manager-kona-lanes-segerstroms|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=April 5, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} Kona Lanes hosted the Southern California [[PBA Regional Tour|PBA Open]] twice in 1964; [[Billy Hardwick]] won in April and Jerry Hale in December.{{cite web|title=Southern California PBA Open: Archived Standings|url=http://www.pba.com/Tournaments/FullStandings/235|publisher=Professional Bowlers Association|accessdate=December 10, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Southern California PBA Open: Archived Standings|url=http://www.pba.com/Tournaments/FullStandings/256|publisher=Professional Bowlers Association|accessdate=December 10, 2016}} Longtime general manager Dick Stoeffler,{{efn|During the PBA Southern California Open finals on December 21, 1964, [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC-TV]] announcer [[Chris Schenkel]] referred to Stoeffler as "general manager, part-owner and resident pro".}} known at the time as the producer and host of ''TV Bowling Tournament'' on [[KTLA]],{{cite news|first=Jim|last=Goodwin|title=Heaven Has a New Headliner|url=http://www.californiabowlingnews.com/assets/011807.pdf|work=California Bowling News|format=PDF|page=1|date=January 18, 2007|accessdate=December 10, 2017}} finished third during the televised finals in his own building in December, behind Hale and Hardwick. When Stoeffler rolled back-to-back [[perfect game (bowling)|300 games]] in one league session at Kona in 1968, he was one of only four men in the United States to have managed the feat.{{cite news|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2011/Gloversville%20NY%20Leader%20Herald/Gloversville%20NY%20Leader%20Herald%201968%20Grayscale/Gloversville%20NY%20Leader%20Herald%201968%20Grayscale%20-%200365.pdf|title=Californian Sixth with Consecutive 300 Games|work=Leader-Herald|location=Gloversville, New York|date=February 5, 1968|accessdate=November 14, 2014}}{{efn|The first woman to roll officially recognized back-to-back 300 games was Carol Norman in 1986.{{cite news|author=Staff|url=http://billingsgazette.com/sports/former-wibc-star-turns-attention-to-abc/article_1355eebc-e6df-5146-ba67-814c2f2c410f.html|title=Former WIBC star turns attention to ABC|work=[[Billings Gazette]]|date=June 1, 2002|accessdate=June 26, 2017}}}} ===Peak years=== Champions who bowled at Kona Lanes during its 45-year history include three-time [[Professional Bowlers Association]] Tour winner [[Jack Biondolillo]];{{sfnp|Grasso|Hartman|2014|p=47}} six-time male [[Bowling Writers Association of America Bowler of the Year]] and future PBA Hall of Famer [[Don Carter (bowler)|Don Carter]];{{sfnp|Grasso|Hartman|2014|p=80}} John Haveles, an [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] Bowling Hall of Fame inductee who began a stint as Kona's manager in 1974;{{cite news|first=Fred|last=Groh|title=Linbrook Bowl's John Haveles Retires|url=http://www.delriolanes.com/bowlingnews//032813.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001342/http://www.delriolanes.com/bowlingnews//032813.pdf|work=California Bowling News|format=PDF|page=4|date=March 28, 2013|archivedate=March 4, 2016|accessdate=December 31, 2013|deadurl=yes}} future [[Michigan]] Women's Bowling Association Hall of Famer Cora Fiebig; two-time female BWAA Bowler of the Year Aleta Sill;{{cite news|first=Gerald|last=Scott|title=WIBC Tournament: Bowlers Wrapping Up 3-Month Event|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-06-30/sports/sp-174_1_bowlers|work=Los Angeles Times|url-access=limited|date=June 30, 1986|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} and [[Barry Asher]], the multiple PBA Tour champion and Hall of Fame inductee who later ran the [[pro shop]] at Fountain Bowl in nearby [[Fountain Valley, California|Fountain Valley]].{{harvp|Horvitz|2002|loc=p. 116}}.{{indent|3}}{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Larsen|title=Bringing the Bowling to 'The Big Lebowski'|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/asher-500841-bowling-lebowski.html|work=[[Orange County Register]]|location=Santa Ana, California|date=March 21, 2013|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} Kona Lanes and [[Tustin, California|Tustin]] Lanes hosted nearly 10,000 teams of five players each taking part in the [[United States Bowling Congress]] Women's Championships in 1986.{{sfnp|USBC|2013|pp=3, 22}} Under Dick Stoeffler's management, Kona Lanes kept busy 24 hours a day, which made him one of the most successful proprietors in the country. Stoeffler met his future wife there, and other couples had similar experiences.{{cite news|first=Scott|last=Martelle|title=O. C. Bowling Alley's Days Roll to an End|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/may/27/local/me-kona27|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url-access=limited|date=May 27, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013}}{{cite news|first=Anthony|last=Pignataro|title=Goodbye, Nude Bowling: The Last Days of Kona Lanes|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/2003-05-15/features/goodbye-nude-bowling/full/|work=OC Weekly|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=May 8, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231172733/http://www.ocweekly.com/2003-05-15/features/goodbye-nude-bowling/full/|archivedate=December 31, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Articles About Bowling Alley|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/keyword/bowling-alley|type=search result|accessdate=February 2, 2014}}{{efn|At least one wedding was performed on the [[Ten-pin bowling#Summary|approach]].{{cite news|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1988/Bright-and-Brief/id-55471ef1be301b656016acdcc887a981|title=Bright and Brief|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=October 11, 1988 |accessdate=November 14, 2014}}}} Kona was often so busy that customers had to make reservations to get a lane during open (non-league) bowling hours.{{cite news|first=Kent M.|last=Paul|title=Community Commentary: A Few Strikes Against Modern Bowling|url=http://www.latimes.com/tn-dpt-0612-commcomm-20110611-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 11, 2011|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} At its peak, Kona Lanes averaged more than 80 lines on each of its 40 lanes.{{cite news|last=Lyou|first=Joe|url=http://www.californiabowlingnews.com/assets/011807.pdf|title=Tenpin Slants|work=California Bowling News|format=PDF|page=2|date=January 18, 2007|accessdate=December 10, 2017}}{{efn|Industry standard: a "line" is a single ten-frame game per person.{{cite web|last=Fong|first=Cory|url=https://www.nd.gov/tax/data/upfiles/media/gl-21822.pdf|format=PDF|title=Guideline–Sales Tax–Bowling Alleys: Charges for Bowling|publisher=[[North Dakota|State of North Dakota]]|date=April 1997|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}{{indent|3}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ecasd.us/ECASD/media/Memorial-High-School/BowlingStudyGuide.pdf|format=PDF|title=Bowling Study Guide: Rules and Scoring|publisher=[[Eau Claire Area School District]]|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}}} Bowling as a participation sport flourished in the early 1960s,{{cite news|first=Jan|last=Norman|title=34 Years of Bowling is Enough|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/bowling-237439-mann-jack.html|work=Orange County Register|location=Santa Ana, California|date=March 4, 2010|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} but its popularity was diluted due to overbuilding; the number of bowling alleys sanctioned by the then-[[United States Bowling Congress|American Bowling Congress]] peaked at about 11,000 by mid-decade,{{cite news|first=Jesus|last=Sanchez|title=Ralph Cramden Might Not Recognize the New Bowling Center|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-08-30/business/fi-1356_1_bowling-shoes|work=Los Angeles Times|url-access=limited|date=August 30, 1988|accessdate=February 6, 2014}} and Kona was one of more than 30 in southern California alone. A decline in league bowling starting in the 1980s was also blamed for the downturn,{{sfnp|Chattel, Inc.|2013|p=17}} but an [[American Machine and Foundry|AMF Bowling]] official argued that the customer base remained steady because an increase in open bowling made up for fewer league bowlers.{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Newman|title=Not a Gutter Ball Yet|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-05-28/news/export23440_1_segerstrom-kona-lanes-amf-bowling/2|page=2|date=May 28, 2003|accessdate=January 2, 2014}} [[File:Kona Lanes 1960–2002.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Kona Lanes in 1960 (top) and in 2002]] Jack Mann bought Kona Lanes in 1980 and re-branded it New Kona Lanes the following year.{{cite web|url=http://businessprofiles.com/details/new-kona-lanes-inc/US-CA-C1051387|title=New Kona Lanes, Inc., California|website=BusinessProfiles|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} Mann's family owned several bowling centers in the region; he was behind the creation of Fountain Bowl in 1973 and the short-lived Regal Lanes in [[Orange, California|Orange]] in 1974. He also owned Tustin Lanes before selling it to his youngest son, Alex.{{efn|After 38 years in business, Tustin Lanes closed in October 2015. The ''[[Orange County Register]]'' called it "the latest victim of the shrinking bowling industry".{{cite news|last=Edwards Staggs|first=Brooke|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/lanes-686666-tustin-hardware.html|title=Shuttered Tustin Lanes to become Orchard Supply Hardware|work=Orange County Register|location=Santa Ana, California|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 17, 2015}}}} Mann bought Kona not because he loved bowling, but because it would continue to pay dividends if he was no longer able to work.{{efn|In 2003, Mann said, "Ironically, nobody in my family is a bowler."}} He later sold Kona to his son Jack Jr. ===Music=== The center's lounge, known as the Outrigger Room, hosted many local artists over the years. Jazz quintet The Redd Foxx Bbq released four songs recorded there, and Roscoe Holland recorded a set of eight live performances for his album ''Beyond the Reef''.{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/label/323722-Kona-Lanes|title=Kona Lanes (venue page)|publisher=discogs|accessdate=September 12, 2014}} In later years, much of the bowlers' area was taped off for rock concerts and weekend promotions like Club Crush, which proved popular among teenagers and also led to album recordings.{{cite news|last=Buffa|first=Peter|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-03-02/news/export26658_1_kona-lanes-orange-county-mesa-verde-center|title=Bye, Kona Lanes and Tiki Googie|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=March 2, 2003|accessdate=September 12, 2014}}{{indent|3}}{{cite news|last=Pasillas|first=Gena|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/aug/20/entertainment/ca-14703|title=Guitar Alley|work=Los Angeles Times|url-access=limited|date=August 20, 1998|accessdate=October 28, 2014}}{{indent|3}}{{cite AV media|people=Instagon|url=http://instagon.bandcamp.com/track/nebula-chaser|title=Space 1999 ''(10th Anniversary Edition)''|format=[[MP3]]|location=Tracks 5–7|date=December 23, 2009|accessdate=November 14, 2014}} A planned event featuring a local [[punk rock]] group was shut down by the [[Costa Mesa Police Department]], leading to negative publicity.{{efn|[[U.S. Bombs]]' promoter said the band was being accused of promoting [[Nazism]]; a police sergeant replied that it was merely an issue of permits.{{cite news|first=Rich|last=Kane|title=Police On My Back|work=OC Weekly|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/1999-08-26/music/police-on-my-back/|date=August 19, 1999|accessdate=January 10, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111035518/http://www.ocweekly.com/1999-08-26/music/police-on-my-back/|archivedate=January 11, 2014|df=mdy-all}}}} ===Decline and demolition=== Kona Lanes continued to lose business to newer centers, despite efforts to appeal to a more diverse customer base by hosting local music acts, supporting a Polynesian-themed restaurant called Kona Korral, and promoting gimmicks like "nude bowling".{{cite news|last=Vanderknyff|first=Rick|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-02-25/news/ol-789_1_bowling-center|title=Strike Up the Music: If You Haven't Bowled Lately, It's Time to Get Back in the Groove|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 25, 1993|accessdate=July 22, 2017|quote=For a time, Kona Lanes in Costa Mesa even advertised 'nude bowling' on its marquee, but it turns out that was just the gag name for a new league. It's not as far-fetched as it sounds, though: an alley in Lake Elsinore used to have a real nude bowling league.}} Eventually, the property became more valuable than the business.{{cite news|last=Edwards Staggs|first=Brooke|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/bowling-689067-lanes-league.html|title=Orange County's fading bowling alley scene: just 15 centers remain|work=Orange County Register|location=Santa Ana, California|date=October 25, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2015}} The landowners, [[C.J. Segerstrom & Sons]], gave Jack Mann Jr. a choice: spend $10–20 million to update the center, or give it up. Mann chose the latter rather than spend such a sum on a site without a long-term lease.{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Newman|title=Not a Gutter Ball Yet|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-05-28/news/export23440_1_segerstrom-kona-lanes-amf-bowling|page=1|date=May 28, 2003|accessdate=January 2, 2014}}{{efn|In a letter to the ''[[Daily Pilot]]'' thanking Kona Lanes' customers, Jack Mann Jr. called the expense prohibitive, and said the landlords were not to blame.{{cite news|last=Mann|first=Jack Jr.|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-04-08/news/export25124_1_kona-lanes-segerstroms-bowling|title=Simple change is Kona Lanes' end|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=April 8, 2003|accessdate=August 15, 2015|quote=The unavoidable truth is that the nature of bowling and recreation in general has changed since Kona Lanes was constructed more than 40 years ago. Upgrading the existing Kona Lanes facility to modern bowling standards and current building codes would be prohibitively expensive. It would be equally costly to tear it down to build a new bowling center from scratch. No one is to blame, and it is inappropriate to target the Segerstroms, who have been excellent landlords.}}}} Plans to build a [[Kohl's]] department store on the site occupied by Kona Lanes and the already-closed [[Regal Entertainment Group#Edwards Theatres|Edwards Cinema Center]] and [[Ice Capades#Chalet skating rinks|Ice Capades Chalet]] were approved by the city's planning commissioners, but they were met with resistance by neighbors who did not believe the store was a [[neighbourhood character|good fit]] for the area. Then-mayor Karen Robinson complained that Costa Mesa's policy-makers were discarding recreation as part of the quality of residents' lives, and appealed the commissioners' decision in February 2003.{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Newman|title=Mayor Plans Appeal of Kona Lanes Vote|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-02-28/news/export26731_1_mesa-verde-homeowners-assn-robin-leffler-costa-mesa|date=February 28, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} The city council later rejected the proposal.{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Newman|title=Costa Mesa Rakes Over the Kohl's|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-04-09/news/export25088_1_segerstrom-sons-costa-mesa-kohl|date=April 9, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} The continuing efforts to [[architectural conservation|save Kona Lanes]] failed; it closed for good in May 2003 and was demolished soon after.{{cite news|last=Newman|first=Dierdre|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-05-31/news/export23343_1_bowling-alley-segerstroms-kona-lanes|title=Demolition nears for Kona Lanes bowling|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=May 31, 2003|accessdate=August 15, 2015}}{{efn|Sister center Java Lanes was leveled the following year.{{cite web|url=http://www.preservela.com/archives/000150.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304085023/http://www.preservela.com/archives/000150.html|title=Alert: Java Lanes|website=PreserveLA.com|date=April 13, 2004|archivedate=March 4, 2016|accessdate=December 10, 2016|deadurl=yes}}{{indent|3}}{{cite web|last=Cohn|first=Matt|url=https://www.lbpost.com/life/arts-culture/2000003626-java-lanes-remembered-as-long-beach-s-tiki-space-age-fun-place|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427141417/http://lbpost.com/life/arts-culture/2000003626-java-lanes-remembered-as-long-beach-s-tiki-space-age-fun-place|title=Java Lanes Remembered As Long Beach's Tiki, Space-Age Fun Place|work=Long Beach Post|date=April 28, 2014|archivedate=April 27, 2016|accessdate=December 10, 2016|deadurl=yes}} Powers, Daly, & DeRosa's other Googie-styled center, Anaheim Bowl, was demolished previously.{{cite news|last=Fernandez|first=Maria Elena|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/oct/24/local/me-25759|title=History and the Style of the Future: Googie Architecture Is Obsolete, But ... |work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 24, 1999|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}}} ===Rezoning and new use=== The 7.5-[[acre]] parcel was [[zoning|rezoned]] in 2010 for senior housing that was expected to provide a new customer base for the restaurants and retailers already in the area and for commercial developments still to come.{{cite news|first=Martin|last=Brower|title=New Plans for Old Kona Lanes Site|url=http://www.coastmagazine.com/articles/site-1653--.html|work=[[Freedom Communications|Coast Magazine]]|location=Santa Ana, California|date=April 1, 2011|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} The lot had sat unused for about ten years before construction on the 215-unit complex began;{{cite news|first=Bradley|last=Zint|title=Harbor Boulevard getting new look|url=http://www.latimes.com/tn-dpt-me-0924-harbor-boulevard-housing-20140923-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|url-access=limited|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=December 11, 2016}}{{indent|3}}{{cite web|url=http://www.azulonapts.com/news/updates-from-azulon-at-mesa-verde/|title=Updates from Azulón at Mesa Verde|publisher=Azulón at Mesa Verde|date=October 4, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} Azulón at Mesa Verde opened in 2014.{{cite news|last=Zint|first=Bradley|title=55-and-Older Complex Opens in Costa Mesa|url=http://www.latimes.com/tn-dpt-me-1220-azulon-costa-mesa-20141219-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 19, 2014|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} Several dozen palm and eucalyptus trees were saved and replanted on the site.{{cite news|last=Francis|first=Kedric|url=http://www.coastmagazine.com/articles/touring-3124-visitors-aesthetic.html|title=The Azulón Aesthetic|work=Coast Magazine|location=Santa Ana, California|date=January 12, 2015|accessdate=April 8, 2015}} ==Legacy== [[File:Kona Lanes ASM 2014.JPG|thumb|upright=1|The surviving KONA LANES section of the sign on display in the American Sign Museum in 2014]] Activity at Kona Lanes increased in its final days, due to the nostalgic value of potential keepsakes. Manager Juanita Johnson said people were asking to buy furniture, office equipment, and more. "Some of that is older than I am." The more substantial items, including the original wood lanes,{{cite news|first=Barbara|last=Thornburg|title=Barn Becomes Home in Renovation|url=http://www.latimes.com/features/home/la-hm-gash24-2009oct24,0,3502104.story|work=Los Angeles Times|url-access=limited|date=October 24, 2009|accessdate=January 2, 2014}}{{indent|3}}{{cite news|first=Cindy|last=McNatt|title=OC Home: November 2013|url=http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/freedom/ochome_201311/index.php?startid=24|work=Orange County Register|location=Santa Ana, California|pages=24–26|date=November 17, 2013|accessdate=January 13, 2014}} had been sold off prior to demolition, while [[dumpster diving|dumpster divers]] hit the parking lot each day, looking for any items of interest. The loss of Kona Lanes was a repeated topic at political events. One Costa Mesa city council candidate said he made a commitment to public service when the building was torn down with little resistance.{{cite news|first=Mona|last=Shadia|title=McEvoy: No Ties, No Strings|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2010-10-12/news/tn-dpt-1013-mcevoy-20101012_1_license-fees-viewpoints-math-teacher|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=October 12, 2010|accessdate=January 4, 2014|quote=[Chris McEvoy:] I remember hearing rumors of it getting torn down, but we never thought it would happen. But it got torn down. I was just so surprised that I didn't hear local officials kicking and screaming. At the time, a whole bunch of my buddies and I said we'd run.}} Another would-be council member agreed that the demolition should never have happened.{{cite news|first=Niyaz|last=Pirani|title=Economy, Recreation Hot Topics at Costa Mesa Forum|url=http://www.ocregister.com/news/candidates-110203-city-mesa.html|work=Orange County Register|location=Santa Ana, California|date=October 23, 2008|accessdate=January 4, 2014}} In 2012, Costa Mesa made plans to upgrade The Triangle, a retail space along Harbor Boulevard two miles south of the Kona Lanes site. Those plans featured a 10-lane bowling alley that opened in 2014.{{cite news|last=Bordas|first=Alexandria|title=Alley Owner Hopes to Pin Down Success|url=http://www.latimes.com/tn-dpt-me-0312-tavern-and-bowl-20140312-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 13, 2014|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} One city official said the center answered residents' longtime call for a new, upscale bowling facility.{{cite news|first=Sarah|last=Peters|title=Revitalization in the Works for Triangle Square|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2012-04-03/news/tn-dpt-0404-triangle-20120403_1_bowling-alley-triangle-square-greenlaw-partners|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=April 3, 2012|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} ===Historic roadside sign=== The huge, neon-lit KONA LANES BOWL sign was featured in publications by the Costa Mesa Historical Society, along with ''The Book of Tiki'' and ''Tiki Road Trip'';{{harvp|Kirsten|2000|p=197}}; {{harvp|Teitelbaum|2007|pp=84, 234}}; {{harvp|CMHS|2016|p=112}}. it also inspired professional paintings,{{cite web|title=Kona Lanes|url=http://www.tmichaelward.com/pages/konalanesnew.htm|website=Paintings by Michael Ward|accessdate=December 31, 2013}}{{indent|3}}{{cite web|title=Kona Lanes Bowling Painting Reproduction from Ross Studio|url=http://ross-art.com/ross-art.com/reproductions/other-themes/kona-lanes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219063402/http://ross-art.com/ross-art.com/reproductions/other-themes/kona-lanes|website=The Neon Road|archivedate=February 19, 2014|accessdate=September 12, 2014}} and was one of several Costa Mesa landmarks memorialized in a mural painted on the local Floyd's 99 Barbershop.{{cite news|last=Casiano|first=Louis Jr.|url=http://www.ocregister.com/2017/08/07/barbershop-to-display-mural-with-iconic-costa-mesa-businesses/|title=45-foot mural at Floyd’s 99 Barbershop will feature Mike Ness, Cuckoo’s Nest|work=The Orange County Register|date=August 7, 2017|accessdate=September 6, 2017}} In 2003, Costa Mesa Planning Commissioner Katrina Foley led an effort to save the sign from the scrap heap. Thanks in part to a private donation,{{cite news|first=Paul|last=Clinton|title=Piece of Kona Lanes to Live On|work=[[Daily Pilot]]|location=Costa Mesa|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2003-06-24/news/export22597_1_bowling-alley-american-sign-museum-paul-clinton|date=June 24, 2003|accessdate=December 31, 2013|quote=... a crane ... removed the massive sign from its spot at the Mesa Verde Shopping Center. ... C. J. Segerstrom and Sons, who owns the center, donated the sign to the museum.}} the marquee was trucked 2,500 miles to Cincinnati, one of the first 20 signs accepted by the American Sign Museum.{{cite news|first1=Amanda|last1=Pennington|first2=Alicia|last2=Robinson|url=http://articles.dailypilot.com/2007-04-29/news/dpt-sundaystory29_1_arches-restaurant-newport-beach-dan-marcheano/8|title=Sunday Story: Our 14 Wonders|page=8|work=Daily Pilot|location=Costa Mesa, California|date=April 29, 2007|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} The "Kona Lanes" portion was refurbished and put on permanent display; the larger "Bowl" section buckled and tore during the unloading process and could not be saved.{{cite web|last=Swormstedt|first=Tod|title=We recently provided a minor contribution ...|url=https://www.facebook.com/americansignmuseum/posts/3914247431420|publisher=[[American Sign Museum]]|via=[[Facebook]]|date=January 29, 2014|accessdate=January 29, 2014|quote=Picking the smaller 'Kona Lanes' section went fine ... the larger 'BOWL' section did not go as well: as the sign was raised off the trailer, the sign began to bend in the middle and the crane cable loosened. The crane operator quickly raised the boom to tighten the cable, but the sign began to tear apart in the middle ... almost in two jagged sections. ... The sign was basically unsalvageable and was scrapped.}}{{indent|3}}{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/story/13338|title=American Sign Museum|website=[[RoadsideAmerica.com]]|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015}} ==See also== * [[Ten-pin bowling]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book|author=((Chattel, Inc.))|url=http://www.smgov.net/departments/PCD/agendas/Landmarks-Commission/2013/20130909/Chattel%20report%20%28234%20Pico%29.pdf|title=234 Pico Boulevard Historic Resource Assessment|publisher=[[Santa Monica, California|City of Santa Monica]]|format=PDF|date=June 24, 2013|accessdate=October 11, 2014|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|author=Costa Mesa Historical Society|title=Costa Mesa: 1940–2003|publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-4671-1576-6|date=2016|ref={{sfnRef|CMHS|2016}}}} * {{cite book|last1=Grasso|first1=John|last2=Hartman|first2=Eric R.|title=Historical Dictionary of Bowling|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|isbn=978-0-8108-8022-1|date=2014|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|title=Engineering News Record|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]]|volume=163|page=126|isbn=|date=1959|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|title=The Big Book of Jewish Sports Heroes: An Illustrated Compendium of Sports History and the 150 Greatest Jewish Sports Stars|last=Horvitz|first=Peter S.|publisher=S.P.I. Books, Inc.|isbn=1-56171-907-2|date=2002|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Hurley|first=Andrew|title=Diners, Bowling Alleys and Trailer Parks: Chasing the American Dream in Postwar Consumer Culture|publisher=[[Basic Books]]|isbn=978-0-465-03187-0|date=2002|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Kirsten|first=Sven A.|title=The Book of Tiki|date=2000|publisher=Taschen|isbn=978-3-8228-6417-3|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Teitelbaum|first=James|title=Tiki Road Trip: A Guide to Tiki Culture in North America|year=2007|publisher=Santa Monica Press|edition=2nd|isbn=978-1-59580-019-0|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|url=http://usbcongress.http.internapcdn.net/usbcongress/bowl/tournaments/pdfs/usbcwomenschamp/2013/2013WCProgramYearbook.pdf|title=Women's Championships Program Yearbook 2013|author=[[United States Bowling Congress]]|year=2013|format=PDF|via=Internap|accessdate=October 11, 2014|ref={{sfnRef|USBC|2013}}}} ==External links== {{Commons category multi|Googie architecture|Kona Lanes|width=18em}} * [http://www.roadsidepeek.com/roadusa/southwest/california/socal/socalbowling/konalanes/index.htm Lost Treasures Kona Lanes at Roadside Peek] (includes several images pre- and post-1980s remodel and from the demolition, plus an interactive Google Street View image from 2011) * [http://synthetrix.com/bowl/index.htm Synthetrix Photos of the Forgotten - 50s Bowling Alleys] (includes nine images of Kona Lanes in its final days and two from the demolition) * [https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=%22kona+lanes%22 Kona Lanes videos at YouTube] (includes concerts and footage of the demolition) {{portalbar|Architecture|California|Sports}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kona Lanes}} [[Category:1958 establishments in California]] [[Category:2003 disestablishments in California]] [[Category:Bowling alleys]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1958]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Costa Mesa, California]] [[Category:Defunct entertainment venues]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures in California]] [[Category:Futurist architecture]] [[Category:Googie architecture in California]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in California]] [[Category:Roadside attractions in California]] [[Category:Ten-pin bowling in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Kubi Indi | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Zimbabwean | other_names = | occupation = Actor | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Kubi Chaza Indi''' is a [[Zimbabwe]]an development activist and businesswoman. Under her maiden name, Kubi Chaza, she was an actress in the [[United Kingdom]], appearing in ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' in 1973 as a sales clerk serving [[James Bond]]. After returning to Zimbabwe, she and actor husband [[John Indi]] started a company making beauty products.
==Background== Indi is very active in the development community, particularly with respect to issues affecting women, and is secretary-general of the Indigenous Business Women's Organisation in Zimbabwe.
The Indis have continued to work in film-making, John as an actor, but Kubi on both sides of the camera. In 1989, she produced ''I Am the Future'', a film about a young woman (played by [[Stella Chiweshe]]) who travels to the big city to escape Zimbabwe's independence war in the rural areas. In 1993, she played the eponymous heroine's modern neighbour in ''Neria'', [[Tsitsi Dangarembga]]'s script about widowhood in Zimbabwe. Both films were directed by [[Godwin Mawuru]], and ''Neria'' featured a soundtrack by [[Oliver Mtukudzi]].
Indi is a member of the Women Filmmakers of Zimbabwe.
==Career== Her role as the sales girl in the Oh Cult Voodoo shop came about when she was in the UK, and she got to play the part. Her character as the sales girl serves James Bond (played by [[Roger Moore]]), wraps an item for him and then rings the Mister Big when Bond leaves the shop.<ref>''3-mob.com'', 4 March 2017 - [http://www.3-mob.com/entertainment/when-a-zimbabwean-girl-appeared-on-a-james-bond-film/#.WYRdnWd--Um When a Zimbabwean girl appeared on a James Bond film…]</ref>
After Zimbabwe became independent, Indi and her husband John returned to the country. There they started their beauty products company called Kubi Cosmetics. It is now a well-known brand in Southern Africa. It makes products that specifically for African skin and hair.<ref>''News Day Zimbabwe'', August 3, 2013 - [https://www.newsday.co.zw/2013/08/03/ocoft-rescues-children-of-jailed-parents/ Ocoft rescues children of jailed parents - Report by Ropafadzo Mapimhidze]</ref>
==Select filmography== *''[[Toomorrow (film)|Toomorrow]]'' (1970) - Sylvana *''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' (1973) - sales clerk (Oh Cult Voodoo Shop, 33 E 65th St, New York City, New York 10065) *''[[Love Thy Neighbour (1973 film)|Love Thy Neighbour]]'' (1973) - first black girl *''[[Royal Flash (film)|Royal Flash]]'' (1975) - Lucy *''[[Neria]]'' (1993) - Connie (final film role)
==References== {{reflist}}
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20051217023236/http://www.africafilmtv.com/pages/filmography/cini.htm ''Africa Film & TV''] Details of ''I Am the Future'' *[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117900756?categoryid=31&cs=1 ''Variety''] Review of ''Neria''
{{authority control}}

/* Origin and evolution */
revision.text:
{{infobox music genre|name= Latin ballad |color=black |bgcolor=palegoldenrod |font color="blue" |stylistic_origins=[[Bolero]], French and Italian ballads |cultural_origins= [[Mexico]], [[Spain]], [[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]] |instruments=Vocal, [[guitar]], [[piano]], [[orchestra]] |popularity= Latin America, Spain, United States |subgenres= |regional_scenes= |other_topics=[[Canción melódica]] }}
'''Latin ballad''' ({{lang-es|balada romántica}}) refers to a music genre derivative of [[Bolero]] that originated in the early-1960s in Latin America and Spain.
Some of the best known artists of the Latin ballad are [[Julio Iglesias]], [[José Luis Rodríguez (singer)|José Luis Rodriguez]], [[Luis Miguel]], [[Camilo Sesto]], [[Emmanuel (singer)|Emmanuel]], [[Nino Bravo]], [[Roberto Carlos (singer)|Roberto Carlos]], [[Ricardo Montaner]], [[Raphael (singer)|Raphael]] and [[José José]] among others. Because of its difficulty, the Latin balladeers are often recognized as skilled singers such as the case of Nino Bravo, José José, Luis Miguel or Raphael.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWSAEGMPXT8][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gyxdmMMdMao]</ref> In recent decades it has become the dominant musical genre of Latin pop.
== Origin and evolution == The Latin or romantic ballad has its origin in the Latin American bolero in the 1950s ([[Lucho Gatica]], [[Leo Marini]]), but also in the romantic song in Italian ([[Nicola Di Bari]]) and French ([[Charles Aznavour]]) in the 1960s and 1970s.
In Mexico, the first ballad recorded as such is "Sonata de Amor" (Sonata of Love) of Mario Álvarez in 1961. In 1965 the famous bolero singer-songwriter [[Armando Manzanero]], sang his first ballad, "Pobres besos míos" (My Poor Kisses).
The heyday of the ballad was reached in the mid-1970s, where artists such as [[José José]], [[Camilo Sesto]], [[Raphael (singer)|Raphael]], [[Roberto Carlos]], [[Rocío Dúrcal]] and others released a big number of hits. The main hits of José José were "El triste" (The Sad One), "La nave del olvido" (The Ship of Forgetfullness), "Te extraño" (I Miss You, also written by Manzanero), "Amar y querer" (To love and To want), or "Gavilán o paloma" (Hawk or Dove), "El pasado" (The Past), "Volcán" (Volcano) or "Lo que no fue no será" (What Never Was Will Never Be). By Roberto Carlos the songs "Amigos" (Friends) or "Detalles" (Details). By Camilo Sesto the hits "Fresa Salvaje" (Wild Strawberry), "Perdóname" (Forgive Me) or "Vivir Así es Morir de Amor" (To Live Like This is to Die of Love). Rocío Dúrcal enjoyed worldwide success and was known as "La Dama de la canción" (The Lady of Song). Her successful ballads include "Costumbres" (Customs), "Amor Eterno" (Eternal Love), "Diferentes" (Different), among many others that were released in Latin America.[2] These songs are widely known today in Latin America.
In the course of their existence the genre merged with diverse rhythms to form several variants, such as romantic [[salsa music|salsa]] and [[cumbia]] aside others.
From the 1990s, globalization and media internationalization processes that integrated contributed to the ballad's spread international spread and further homogenize around a common Latin identity. As part of the Latin Americanization of the United States and the dominant presence in the genre of multinational record labels, [[Miami]] has become the main producer of ballads<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090611214939/http://www.saintmarys.edu/~dparty/pdf/Balada%20y%20Transnacionalismo.pdf ''Transnacionalización y la balada latinoamericana'' (In spanish:Transnationalization and the ballad Latin - American), por Daniel Party, University of Pennsylvania, 2003, pag. 6]</ref> which in turn has fed back trends of migration of Latino and Hispanic performers, producers and musicians to that city. By the turn of the 2010s however, Latin ballads have begun to lose popularity as uptempo Latin genres such as [[bachata (music)|bachata]], [[reggaeton]], and Spanish-language [[electropop]] music have gained popularity with the Hispanic audience in the radio.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cobo|first1=Leila|authorlink1=Leila Cobo|title=Latin Noise: We Want Our Ballads|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/latin-notas/6244251/latin-music-we-want-our-ballads|website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=8 September 2015|date=10 September 2014}}</ref>
== Features == The ethnomusicologist Daniel Party defines the romantic ballad as "a love song of slow tempo, played by a solo singer accompanied by an orchestra usually" .<ref name="saintmarys.edu">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090611214939/http://www.saintmarys.edu/~dparty/pdf/Balada%20y%20Transnacionalismo.pdf ''Transnacionalización y la balada latinoamericana'' (In spanish:Transnationalization and the ballad Latin - American), by Daniel Party, University of Pennsylvania, 2003, pag. 1]</ref>
The ballad and bolero are often confused and songs can fall in one or the other category without too much presicion. The distinction between them is referring primarily to a more sophisticated and more metaphorical language and subtle bolero, compared with a more direct expression of the ballad.
Party stressed that the romantic ballad derive from "Latin common sensibility"<ref name="saintmarys.edu"/> He draws on the research of Jesus Martin-Barbero to highlight that the romantic ballad is an expression of a broader cultural process, called by Martin-Barbero as "emotional integration in Latin America", a phenomenon that would explain a generalization of the ways of feeling and express the emotions of the Latinos, through gestures, sounds, rhythms and cadences common literary devices, linked in turn to the [[telenovela]].<ref>Martín-Barbero, Jesús. "Memory and Form in the Latin American Soap Opera." To Be Continued...: Soap Operas around the World. Ed. Robert Clyde Allen. London: Routledge, 1995. 276-84.</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Latin music|Music}} * [[Ballad]] * [[Latin pop]] * [[Latin music (genre)]] {{clear}}

{{about|the Lido in Paris|other Lidos|Lido (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|Lido Theatre}} {{Refimprove|date= December 2014}} {{Infobox theatre | name = Le Lido | image = Le Lido.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 116 Avenue des Champs-Élysées | city = Paris | country = France | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|48|52|20.50|N|2|18|2.02|E|display=inline,title}} | architect = Peynet, Bartoccini and Veccia | owner = [[Sodexo]] | tenant = | operator = | capacity = 1150 | type = [[Cabaret]] | opened = June 20th 1946,<ref name="Founders">{{cite web|title=The Founders|url=http://www.lido.fr/en/myth.html|website=Lido.fr|publisher=Le Lido|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> current location since 1977 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.lido.fr/|lido.fr}} }} '''Le Lido''' is a [[cabaret]] and [[burlesque]] show located on the [[Champs-Élysées]] in [[Paris]], [[France]]. It opened in 1946 at 78 Avenue des Champs -Élysée and moved to its current location in 1977. It is known for its exotic shows including dancers, singers, and other performers. Famous names have performed there including: [[Edith Piaf]], [[Siegfried and Roy]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Siegfried and Roy at Lido de Paris|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TbDMvLj9csw|website=Youtube|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> [[Sylvie Vartan]], [[Johnny Hallyday]], [[Maurice Chevalier]], [[Marlene Dietrich]], [[Eartha Kitt]], [[Josephine Baker]], [[Kessler Twins]], [[Elton John]], [[Laurel & Hardy]], [[Dalida]], [[Shirley MacLaine]],<ref name=Maclaine>{{cite web|title=Shirley Maclaine at the Lido|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0330885/|website=IMDB|publisher=Amazon.com inc.|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> [[Mitzi Gaynor]], [[Juliet Prowse]] and [[Noël Coward]].
== History == Founded by Joseph and Louis Clérico, Le Lido opened on June 20, 1946. Le Lido was preceded by an artificial beach in a townhouse basement in the 1920s, running as a nightclub/casino in the late night hours.
In 1955, after a visit by the entertainment director of the [[Stardust Resort and Casino]], Las Vegas, the Clérico brothers along with Donn Arden brought the Lido to the [[Stardust Resort and Casino|Stardust]] Las Vegas. This started a series of imports of Parisian cabaret shows to Las Vegas: [[Follies Bergeres]] to the [[Tropicana Las Vegas|Tropicana]], Nouvelle Eve to [[El Rancho Vegas|Hotel El Rancho Vegas]] and [[Casino de Paris]] to the [[Dunes (hotel and casino)|Dunes]].<ref name="Showgirls Project">{{cite web|title=Lido at the Stardust|url=http://digital.library.unlv.edu/collections/showgirls/lido-stardust|website=Digital Collections at UNLV|publisher=UNLV}}</ref> The Stardust edition of Le Lido closed in 1992.
Le Lido moved in 1977 to the Normandie on the Champs-Élysées.
In 2006, [[Sodexo]], the international food service company, purchased Le Lido and has invested 24 million euro into developing its current show.<ref name=sodexo>{{cite web|title=SODEXO INVESTIT 25 MILLIONS DANS LA REFONTE DU LIDO|url=http://www.hospitality-on.com/actualites/2014/12/01/sodexo-investit-25-millions-dans-la-refonte-du-lido/|website=Hospitality on think tank|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230044205/http://www.hospitality-on.com/actualites/2014/12/01/sodexo-investit-25-millions-dans-la-refonte-du-lido/|archivedate=2014-12-30|df=}}</ref>
== Show == The Lido was closed from December 2, 2014, to April 2, 2015, while a new version of the show was prepared. <ref name="lido mainpage">{{cite web|title=Lido|url=http://www.lido.fr|website=Le Lido|publisher=Le Lido|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> The new version was developed by [[Franco Dragone]]. Each version of Le Lido is made up of 10–20 scenes and runs for about an hour and a half. Two shows are run every day of the week. A pre-show dinner is offered with the first evening show of each day at an additional cost.
Each Le Lido show features singers and dancers, which always include the famous Bluebell Girls.<ref name="Guardian_obit">{{cite web|last1=Gentlemen|first1=Amelia|title=Founder of Bluebell Girls dies at 94|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/sep/15/france.arts|website=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> A few featured dancers, showgirls and lead singers may be added. The Lido is known for its spectacular costumes featuring thousands of dollars in feathers and rhinestones, rich fabrics, and top quality furs.
The opening or "theme" scene welcomes the audience and sets the tone for the evening. It may also set the colour scheme for the show and will feature special effects and lighting. Music may be original or a medley of current popular songs mixed with music from Broadway or Hollywood films; often the opening number is a potpourri of styles and performers may change costumes several times. Between the production numbers, specialty "vaudeville/cabaret" acts are featured, such as jugglers, acrobats or magicians. At least one scene will feature water effects – another thing the Lido is known for. The stage itself can be raised and lowered, may change back and forth into an ice rink or swimming pool, and can feature elaborate set pieces which come up from below. The closing number often features a number called "Merci Beaucoup" (featured in the television show Shirley Maclaine at The Lido de Paris) and usually has some particularly spectacular costumes.
Among the last of its kind, the Lido has a special place in the history of nightclubs and floorshows and continues a tradition of the "naughty but nice" opulent production shows originally started by The [[Follies Bergeres]].
==Bluebell Girls== [[File:MargaretKellyGirls.jpg|thumbnail|right|Margaret with the Bluebell Girls in 1948]] Founded by [[Margaret Kelly (dancer)|Margaret Kelly]], also known as Miss Bluebell, the dancers of the Lido are known as the Bluebell Girls. Until her retirement in 1986, each dancer was hand-selected by Kelly. Then the dancers were under the direction of Pierre Rambert until his retirement in Dec 2014.<ref name="Guardian_obit" /> According to the [[Forbes]], they are "some of the world’s most beautiful and talented burlesque dancers".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rooksanahossenally/2016/09/26/5-reasons-the-champs-elysees-avenue-in-paris-is-still-worth-visiting/#3bd9ab5fa602|title=5 Things to do When Visiting the Champs Elysées in Paris|last=Hossenally|first=Rooksana|date=2016-09-26|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-22|language=en}}</ref>
The cast comes from all over the world, and are noted for their statuesque height, averaging a height of 5' 11". It is interesting that while many of the performers in the shows are French a large number come from the UK and many of the tall statuesque "showgirls" who may top 6 feet without heels may come from South Africa and the USA.
With the fall of the Soviet Union, showgirls and classically trained dancers now come from Ukraine and many other former Soviet states.
==Production history== Every few years, Le Lido develops a new version of its show. The show used to change more frequently, now each iteration may run for several years until the management feels it has run its course and a new production is called for. Each show can take millions of dollars to develop. The following are the titles of each show produced by the Le Lido:<ref>{{cite web|title=Former Shows|url=http://www.lido.fr/en/myth.html#b3|website=Le Lido|publisher=Le Lido|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> *1946 – Sans Rimes Ni Raisons *1946 – Mississippi *1947 – Made in Paris *1948 – Confetti *1949 – Bravo *1950 – Enchantment *1951 – Rendez-vous *1953 – Voilà *1954 – Desirs *1955 – Voulez-vous *1956 – C'est Magnifique *1957 – Prestige *1959 – Avec Plaisir *1961 – Pour Vous *1962 – Suivez-Moi *1964 – Quelle Nuit *1966 – Pourquoi Pas? *1969 – Grand Prix *1971 – Bonjour La Nuit *1972 – Grand Jeu *1977 – Allez Lido *1981 – Cocorico *1985 – Panache *1990 – Bravissimo *1994 – C'est Magique *2003 – Bonheur (closed December 2, 2014) *2015 – Paris Merveilles (Paris Wonders)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lido.fr/nouveau-spectacle.html|title=Spectacle|work=Le Lido|accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref>
==Media Featuring Le Lido== ''Shirley Maclaine at the Lido'' (1979) produced by Gary Smith and Dwight Hemion – Nominated for a Primetime Emmy for Outstanding Comedy-Variety or Music Program.<ref name=Maclaine />
The Bluebell Girls were featured in a 1960 episode of ''Close-Up'', a Canadian TV show broadcast on the [[Canadian Broadcast Corporation|CBC]]<ref>http://www.cbc.ca/archives/entry/close-up-goes-to-france</ref><ref>http://www.cbc.ca/player/play/1869406343</ref>
Numerous clips of several of the shows of the last 20 years and even full videos of all the production numbers from some editions are available on YouTube.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3r6iOIP2eeY</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7M5OzbgghV4</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/user/LeLidoDeParis/videos</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|France|Paris|Theatre}} *[[Folies Bergere]] *[[Moulin Rouge]] * [[Jubilee!]] * [[Peepshow (burlesque)|Peepshow]] * [[Sirens of TI]]<!-- * [[Fashionistas]]<ref>https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/mike-weatherford/fashionistas/</ref> --> * [[Absinthe (show)|Absinthe]]<!-- * [[Lido de Paris]] --><!-- * [[Enter the Night]] --><!-- * [[Minsky's Follies ]] --> * [[Casino de Paris]] * [[Paradis Latin]] * [[Cabaret Red Light]] * [[Tropicana Club]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Lido (cabaret)}} * [http://www.lido.fr Lido Official website] * https://www.youtube.com/user/LeLidoDeParis/videos

|- |[[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Dark match|Dark]] |Bettie Rage defeated Diana Hall |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |- |1 |Angie Skye defeated [[Catherine Power|Cat Power]] |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |- |2 |Kaitlin Diemond defeated Jasmin |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |- |3 |Mary Lee Rose, Pink Flash Kira and [[Vanessa Kraven]] defeated [[Sassy Stephie]], Anna Minoushka and Jody D'Milo (with Mademoiselle Rachelle) |[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Multiple man teamed matches|Six-woman tag team match]] |- |4 |Sweet Cherrie defeated [[Saraya Knight]] |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] under British Rules |- |5 |Deziree defeated Mistress Belmont |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |- |7 |[[LuFisto]] defeated [[Nikki Storm]] |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |- |8 |[[Mercedes Martinez]] (c) defeated Missy, Angie Skye and [[Leah Von Dutch]] |[[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|Four-way elimination match]] for the [[nCw Femmes Fatales Championship]] |- |9 |[[Courtney Rush]] vs. [[Cheerleader Melissa]] ended in a time limit draw |30-Minute [[Iron Man match|Iron Woman match]] |- |colspan="10"|{{center|(c) – refers to the champion(s) heading into the match}} |- |}

[[File:Bullet Bob Scott Wrestling 2.JPG|thumb|[[Bullet Bob Armstrong|The Bullet]] (left) and [[Mr. Wrestling II]] (right), seen here with [[Scott Armstrong (wrestler)|Scott Armstrong]] (center), were very popular in the [[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA]]'s [[Jim Crockett Promotions|Southeastern]] and [[Continental Wrestling Association|Continental wrestling areas]] during the 1980s.]] This is a '''list of [[wrestling mask|masked wrestlers]]'''. The earliest known masked wrestler in the United States was The Masked Marvel who famously "crashed" the international tournament, which featured many of the top stars of the [[History of professional wrestling in the United States#"Farmer" Burns-Frank Gotch era|"Farmer" Burns-Frank Gotch era]], held at the [[Manhattan Center|Manhattan Opera House]] in 1915.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/wrestlingframe.html |title=Pro Wrestling Illustrated: Wrestling History|author=Pro Wrestling Illustrated|authorlink=Pro Wrestling Illustrated|year=2007|publisher=PWI-Online.com}}</ref> In North America, many [[professional wrestlers]] have traditionally worn masks after they had been used in an area, or "territory", that their popularity and drawing ability diminished, it would be an easy way for a wrestler to begin working in a new area as a "fresh face". Sometimes workers wore masks in one territory and unmasked in another territory in order to keep their two identities separate. Several wrestlers used one or two personas for their entire career such as [[Dick Beyer|The Destroyer]] (1962–1984), [[Tim Woods|Mr. Wrestling]] (1965–1983) and [[Bill Eadie|Masked Superstar]] (1976–1986).<ref name="WrestlingMuseum">{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/masks2.html |title=Masked Wreslers |author= |work=From Parts Unknown |publisher=WrestlingMuseum.com |accessdate=}}</ref>
Wrestling masks also have a significant cultural importance in [[lucha libre]], and [[puroresu]] to a lesser extent; famed ''[[luchadore]]s'' such as [[Blue Demon]], [[Mil Máscaras]] and [[El Santo]] have achieved an almost iconic status in Mexico. In Japan, masked wrestlers are also very popular. Many are heavily influenced by [[anime]] and [[manga]] characters such as [[Tiger Mask]] and [[Black Tiger (professional wrestling)|Black Tiger]] during the 1980s, and [[Jushin Thunder Liger]] in the 90s. Many of these stars would appear in [[World Championship Wrestling]] during the "[[Monday Night Wars]]" period.<ref name="WrestlingMuseum"/>
In recent years, [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] has re-used masked characters for comedic purposes. [[Edge and Christian]] donned the masks worn by the [[WWE|WWF]]'s original [[Los Conquistadores]] in their feud with [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|World Tag Team Champions]] [[The Hardy Boyz]] in 2000. Under the guise of [[El Gran Luchadore]], [[Paul London]], [[Shannon Moore]], [[Eddie Guerrero]] and [[Kurt Angle]] each challenged [[John Layfield|JBL]] for the [[WWE Championship]] in 2004. Likewise, [[El Generico]] and [[Shark Boy]] play a similar role on the [[independent circuit]].

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/175.34.187.16|175.34.187.16]] ([[User talk:175.34.187.16|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox person | image = Lorrae Desmond.jpg | caption = Desmond in 2012 | name = Lorrae Desmond | birth_name = Beryl Hunt | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|10|2|df=yes}}{{cite web |url= https://www.austlit.edu.au/austlit/page/8468594 |title= Lorrae Desmond: Biography |publisher= austlit.edu.au |accessdate= 21 April 2017}} | birth_place = [[Mittagong]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = Beryl Gorshenin (married name) | occupation = Retired (actress, singer, entertainer, TV presenter, magazine columnist theatre lyricist) | yearsactive = 1955–1997 | spouse = Alex Gorshenin (1963–1976) | partner = | children = | parents = Alice and Des Hunt | influences = | influenced = | website = | awards =Member of the Order of the British Empire
Logie 1984 – Best Supporting Actress in a Series for: ''A Country Practice'' (1981)
[[Gold Logie]] 1962 }} '''Lorrae Desmond''', [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (2 October 1932), born as '''Beryl Hunt''', is an Australian retired [[Gold Logie]]-award-winning singer, entertainer, character actress and theatre lyricist, with a career that spanned over 60 years, both locally and internationally. She started her career in England, particularly as a singer and radio/television presenter before returning to Australia where she became a popular actress remains best known to early television audiences as presenter of the self-titled musical variety program ''[[The Lorrae Desmond Show]]'' from 1960 until 1964, her live singing performances as a [[forces sweetheart]] and for her soap opera roles including the 1970s in [[Number 96 (TV series)|Number 96]] and her long-running role as Shirley Gilroy an original character from 1981 in the television series ''[[A Country Practice]]'', which she played to 1992. ==Early life and career== Desmond was born on 2 October 1932, in [[Mittagong]], [[New South Wales]], to Alice and Des Hunt. She travelled to Britain in the 1950s, and at 16, as Lorrae started her career as a singing [[cigarette girl (person)|cigarette girl]] and became a celebrity there, she performed as a solo artist and with backing group The Rebels, she appearing in cabaret, pantomime, radio, and live recording, including several shows for the [[BBC]], including ''Meet Lorrae'' and ''Swing with Lorrae''.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27238107 |title=ANOTHER JOY NICHOLS?. |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=29 September 1954 |accessdate=5 April 2011 |page=21 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} She even featured in her own comedy series ''Trouble for Two'' in 1958, was in the cast of several [[Terry-Thomas]] TV specials, and competed to represent the UK in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] in 1957.[http://oneurope.biz/asfe/1950s/1957.htm A Song For Europe 1957], ASFE History Pages In his book ''Bounder'' (2008), Graham McCann states that Desmond might have married Terry-Thomas, who had been her constant companion for seven years. Instead, the actor overcame a 26-year age gap to marry Belinda Cunningham. Desmond refuted this in an ABC interview in April 2008, saying that she dated Thomas for 10 years, but they would never have married.[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/talkingheads/txt/s2209837.htm Lorrae Desmond, ''Talking Heads, with Peter Thompson''] In 1962, she made history by being the first woman to win the Gold [[Logie Award|Logie]] (which was in fact Silver, as women at the time received the Silver Statuette, and men received the Gold Statuette) for her work on her variety show ''The Lorrae Desmond Show''.[http://tvweek.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=272558 "1962: Lorrae Desmond", ''TV Week''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901221618/http://tvweek.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=272558 |date=1 September 2007 }} The [[Gold Logie]] award that year was a dual honour, with [[Tommy Hanlon Jr.]] also winning the coveted trophy. Desmond married Sydney surgeon Dr Alex Gorshenin in 1963.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47510218 |title=LORRAE DESMOND'S WEDDING. |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]]|date=29 May 1963 |accessdate=5 April 2011 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} They travelled to the United States together, where he continued to study. They moved back to Sydney but the marriage did not last long. The [[Australian Government]] invited her to tour Vietnam from 1967 to 1971, to entertain the troops. She was widely courted as being the [[Forces Sweetheart|Australian Forces Sweetheart]], amongst others including [[Little Pattie]].[http://cas.awm.gov.au/item/REL33301.002 Sequin and chiffon entertainer's scarf : Lorrae Desmond], Australian War Memorial. Desmond was appointed a Member of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in 1970 for services to entertainment and the welfare of the Australian Forces in Vietnam.{{cite web|title=Lorrae GORSHENIN MBE|url=http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1085521&search_type=advanced&showInd=true|publisher=Australian Honours Database|accessdate=2007-10-02}}{{London Gazette |issue=45118 |date=13 June 1970 |page=6401|supp=y}} In 2000, Desmond was a supporter of the [[2000 Paralympic Games|Paralympic Games]]. ==Television roles== Desmond's television appearances include ''[[Homicide (Australian TV series)|Homicide]]'', ''[[Number 96 (TV series)|Number 96]]'' (1973) and ''[[Arcade (TV series)|Arcade]]'' (1980). She also had a guest appearance on ''[[Home and Away]]'' as Isobel Dupre. ==''A Country Practice'': Shirley Gilroy== Desmond appeared as Shirley Gilroy in ''[[A Country Practice]]'', an original character, from 1981 to 1992, opposite [[Brian Wenzel]] who played her husband Frank Gilroy. In 1984 she won the Logie for Best Supporting Actress for this role. In one of the series' iconic episodes in 1992, the long-running character Shirley was killed off in an off-screen plane crash, with actress Desmond stating she did not want a prolonged death storyline arc like Molly Jones ([[Anne Tenney]]). ==Writing== Desmond co-wrote the lyrics to the musical ''[[Man of Sorrows (musical)|Man of Sorrows]]'' (originally titled ''Jesus Christ Revolution'') which premiered in Melbourne in 1972.{{Cite news|url=|title=Out-of-town success for new musical|last=|first=|date=4 June 1972|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|access-date=|page=143}} About the industry, she said:
What I really wanted to do was write lyrics for songs. I did do a few weeks in ''Home And Away'' after ''ACP'', but I’m a bit sick of performing—after you've been doing it for 50 years you're just going around in circles! The thing I liked most about being a performer was putting the act together, which is why I've come back to writing. It's still pleasant to be recognised as Shirley because people are always nice to me. And with those ''ACP'' repeats on [[Hallmark]], it goes from generation to generation.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
In 2001, she obtained the rights to write the lyrics for a musical play based on [[Bryce Courtenay]]'s novel ''[[Smoky Joe's Cafe]]'', about the effects of the Vietnam War on a veteran. The play, entitled ''Honey'', premiered in 2007 at the [[Riverside Theatre Parramatta]].[http://www.stagewhispers.com.au/node/1997 Lorrae Desmond – blonde goddess in the golden dress], ''Stage Whispers'', July/August 2008. She was also a magazine columnist for ''[[That's Life! (Australian magazine)|That's Life]]''; she wrote an article called "Ask Lorrae", where readers would write in, asking for advice and information. Desmond took part in an ''A Country Practice'' reunion special in 2006, as part of the "Television Turns 50" celebrations, and the series' 30th-anniversary reunion in 2011.Knox, David: [http://citysearch.com.au/tvguide/1137861630641/TV+reunions+are+hot+property TV reunions are hot property], Citysearch, March 2011. In 2017, Lorrae who was the first female to win a [[Gold Logie]], appeared at the [[Logie Awards of 2017|Logie awards]], to present an award opposite her cousin's son, Chinese Australian actor and presenter [[Sam Pang]]. ==One-woman show== She toured Australia performing in ''[[High Society (musical)|High Society]]'', and her own one-woman show. ==Awards and honours== * 1962: [[Gold Logie Award for Most Popular Personality on Australian Television]] for ''The Lorrae Desmond Show'' * 1970:[[File: Order of the British Empire ribbon.png]] Member of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) for services to entertainment and the welfare of the Australian Forces in Vietnam * 1984: Silver Logie Award – [[Logie Award for Most Outstanding Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress In A Series]] for ''A Country Practice'' * 2009: [[Mo Awards]] – John Campbell Fellowship Award[http://www.moawards.com/?page_id=103 http://www.moawards.com/?page_id=103], Mo Awards, 11 May 2010. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080330194244/http://cafe.showbuzz.com.au/CafePG/actsanda.nsf/9dd88318616c0d62ca2567e1000ca813/d3d6a22cf0a8ff794a256738000093cc?OpenDocument Lorrae Desmond Biography – School of Arts Cafe website] * {{IMDb name|id=0221461|name=Lorrae Desmond}} * [http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=Number%3A358899;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 Lorrae Desmond at the National Film and Sound Archive] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Desmond, Lorrae}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Actresses from New South Wales]] [[Category:Australian entertainers]] [[Category:Gold Logie winners]] [[Category:Australian Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:People from the Southern Highlands (New South Wales)]] [[Category:Australian soap opera actresses]] [[Category:20th-century Australian actresses]] [[Category:20th-century Australian singers]] [[Category:Australian female singers]] revision.text:
{{Infobox theatre | name = Market Street Cinema | native_name = Imperial Theater | image = File:Market Street Cinema.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Market Street Cinema in 2012 | address = 1077 Market Street | city = San Francisco | country = | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|37.780834|-122.4139685|region:US-CA_type:landmark|display=it}} | architect = [[Clifford A. Balch]] | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = 1,485 | type = | opened = December 22, 1912 | reopened = | yearsactive = 101 | rebuilt = | closed = February, 2013 | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = }} '''Market Street Cinema''' is a historical theatre located on [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]] in the [[Mid-Market, San Francisco|Mid-Market district]], [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]]. It was founded in 1912 by David and [[Sid Grauman]] as the Imperial Theater''.''<ref>{{Cite web|title = Let's Break Down the History of the Market Street Cinema|url = http://sf.curbed.com/archives/2013/06/13/lets_break_down_the_history_of_the_market_street_cinema.php|website = Curbed SF|accessdate = 2015-10-24}}</ref> It was converted into a movie theatre as the Premiere Theatre (1929) and the [[United Artists]] Theatre (1931).
The benefit [[Film premiere|world premiere]] of ''Dirty Harry'' was held here<ref>{{cite web|url=http://upfromthedeep.com/mid-market/ |title=1077 Market Street (Grauman's Imperial, 1912; Imperial, 1916; Premier, 1929; United Artists, 1931; Loew's, 1970; Market Street Cinema, 1972) |publisher=Upfromthedeep.com |date= |accessdate=December 20, 2013}}</ref> on December 22, 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diva.sfsu.edu/collections/sfbatv/bundles/185987 |title=KPIX-TV newsclip from the world premiere of ''Dirty Harry'' |publisher=Diva.sfsu.edu |date= |accessdate=December 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://diva.sfsu.edu/bundles/preview/107822 |title=download MPEG4 newsclip |date= |accessdate=December 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723214915/https://diva.sfsu.edu/bundles/preview/107822 |archivedate=July 23, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In 1972 it was renamed Market Street Cinema and was used through the early 2000s as an adult entertainment venue.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Market Street Cinema in San Francisco, CA - Cinema Treasures|url = http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/1187|website = cinematreasures.org|accessdate = 2015-10-24}}</ref> The role of the theatre in San Francisco's sex industry in the 1980s was documented in a photo essay by photographer Leon Mostovoy.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Leon Mostovoy: Market Street Cinema {{!}} ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives at the USC Libraries|url = http://one.usc.edu/market-street-cinema/|website = one.usc.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-24}}</ref> In October 2015, the San Francisco Planning Commission approved a plan to demolish the theatre and replace it with an eight-story building.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Residential complex to replace century-old theater on Market Street - The San Francisco Examiner|url = http://www.sfexaminer.com/residential-complex-to-replace-century-old-theater-on-market-street/|website = The San Francisco Examiner|accessdate = 2015-10-24|language = en}}</ref>
Market Street Cinema is considered [[Haunted house|haunted]] in popular culture: it features in a 2013 episode of ''[[Ghost Adventures]]'' (season 7, episode 25)<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2737936/|title = Ghost Adventures: Market Street Cinema|date = |accessdate = 24 October 2015|website = Internet Movie Database|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and was used as a shooting location by filmmaker Charles Webb for a low-budget horror movie called ''G-String Horror''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What Will Become of the Historic, Quite Possibly Haunted, Market Street Cinema?|url = http://sfist.com/2013/06/10/what_will_become_of_the_historic_qu.php|website = SFist|accessdate = 2015-10-24|first = Jay|last = Barmann|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151101163451/http://sfist.com/2013/06/10/what_will_become_of_the_historic_qu.php|archivedate = 2015-11-01|df = }}</ref>
On August 15, 2016, Mint Minx Press published the novella ''Market Street Cinema'' by author Michele Machado, narrating the fictional account of a dancer working at the club in 1998.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/26876980|title=Market Street Cinema|last=Machado|first=Michele|publisher=Mint Minx Press|year=2016|isbn=0692551352|location=United States|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Mitchell Brothers O'Farrell Theatre]]
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/1187 Market Street Cinema], ''Cinema Treasures'' * {{IMDb episode|tt2737936}}
